summary: This is an internal email chain among prosecutors from the Southern District of New York, dated November-December 2020, outlining a task list for trial preparation in the Ghislaine Maxwell (GM) case. It details planned witness interviews, evidence authentication, and investigative steps, revealing the prosecution's strategy and pending actions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'GM' throughout the document; the subject of email reviews, deposition transcripts, and the central figure in the upcoming trial.

persons.name: Sigrid
persons.context: Mentioned as a person to call regarding a potential interview for the investigation.

events.title: Prosecution team agenda planning
events.description: An agenda email is sent to the prosecution team listing topics and potential next steps for trial preparation in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Task list formalization
events.description: A formal task list based on a team conversation is circulated, detailing specific investigative and preparatory actions with assigned responsibilities and timelines.

events.title: Progress check on trial prep tasks
events.description: A team member checks in on the status of the task list, noting completed or in-motion items related to evidence review, witness interviews, and authentication.

locations: PB house (likely referring to a Palm Beach house searched)
keyFacts: The document reveals the prosecution's active trial preparation for the Ghislaine Maxwell case in late 2020, including plans to interview and re-interview multiple witnesses.
Key tasks included reviewing Ghislaine Maxwell's emails via Relativity, authenticating documents from Epstein's donor relations, and authenticating items from a search of a Palm Beach house.
The prosecution planned to interview a retired employee who managed donor relations with Jeffrey Epstein to authenticate documents.
The team noted the statute of limitations (SOL) was approaching regarding the review of Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition transcripts.
Multiple names and roles (e.g., victims, witnesses, a client, a mother, detectives) are referenced but are redacted in the document, indicating a broad investigative scope.
